prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for ending free rides for their friend. The situation is that the friend often gets rides, but this time the friend put gas in the tank because the author forgot their purse. The author is questioning if they're an asshole for telling the friend to find their own way around now.

First, I need to analyze the dynamics here. The friend has used the author's car many times without contributing to gas. This time, the friend helped by putting in $10 for gas. The author, after being reminded about the purse, ends the rides. The key points are about fairness and reciprocity.

The user wants a judgment on whether the author is in the wrong. The options are A (yes) or B (no). So, is it fair for the author to stop offering rides? Well, the friend's action of putting gas might be a one-time thing, but the author is ending all rides. The author might feel that the friend hasn't contributed before, so this is a fair boundary. On the other hand, the friend did help this time, so maybe the author is overreacting.

But in terms of the question, the author is asking if they're an asshole. The main issue is whether the author had the right to stop the rides. The friend's previous behavior (hundreds of rides without contributing) might justify the author's decision. The author might be setting boundaries, which is reasonable. So the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong. They are asserting their right to control their resources and set limits on how others use them.
